title: What are 10 classic rock songs you wish classic rock radio would avoid playing for at least a year? - Quora

response.answer_text: A bit of fascinating background here. Lee Abrams, whom I worked with at the Chicago Tribune, was largely responsible for picking the artists you hear repeated ad nauseum on classic rock radio. Lee used to be one of Sam Zell’s radio hotshots when he owned Jacor Communications. The other, Randy Michaels, gave us ultra-right talk radio. As executives for Chicago’s Tribune Company, both were miserable failures who left in disgrace for sexual indiscrepancies, though not with each other. The sad part is otherwise great bands and albums from that period (The Pretty Things, Four Seasons in their experimental period, the Association, Three Dog Night) did not make Abrams’ cut and rarely get played on classic rock (or is that Jurassic?) rock radio. And so, the songs. Ban them not for a year, but 10, to return as re-recorded klezmer favorites, sung in Yiddish: The Who, “Won’t Get Fooled Again.” Anything from “Who’s Next,” really… but this finger-to-the-establishment song is now anything but. Close your ears and you can hear the coda, followed by a Viagra-popping, toupee wearing Boomer deejay singing its praises for the 1,453rd time. In a smug voice.Close second: “Can’t Explain” 2. Pink Floyd, “”Money.” Don’t gimme none of that goody good good ultra-heavy-rotation-playing bullshit. Close second: “Another Brick In the Wall.” 3. Led Zeppelin, “Over the Hills and Far Away.” The next Jimmy Page riff after “Stairway to Heaven” that we should ban pimply teens from playing in music stores. Close second: “Black Dog” 4. Rolling Stones, “Honky Tonk Women.” More cowbell! More cowbell! More fucking cowbell!!! Close second: “Sympathy For the Devil.” 5. Crosby, Stills and Nash, “Carry On.” How about “Carrie Anne” by Graham Nash's Wimpy former band, The Hollies? For a change. At least the steel drum solo would make me spit out my granola. Close second: “Suite: Judy Blue Eyes.” Honorable mention: “Our House,” Graham Nash. Number one uncontested winner of the Pussy Whipped Rock Song of the Millennium. Imagine the woman in the song yelling at Nash to take out the goddam trash, and Nash cooing back “Yes dear! Oh yes dear!!!” 6. The Hollies, “Long Cool Woman In a Black Dress.” The Hollies had only one hope of being cool, and that’s after Nash left. Still a great song, but getting to the point of Earworm Central. And just try making out the lyrics. “I toll ya gonni SPID coz ya gonna be sid.” Huh? Close second: “Bus Stop” 7. Bad Company, “Shooting Star.” Shoot the deejay instead. Johnny died one night and it was from this song TAKING OVER HIS BRAIN. Close second: “Rock and Roll Fantasy” 8. Eddie Money, “Two Tickets to Paradise.” The former Eddie Mahoney was a cop, and he should arrest the programming director for highjacking. I’ve got a surprise especially for you, but it’s not the song coming on the radio. The most thinly veiled attempt at a Macho Man’s Plot to Launch a Weekend Sex Marathon. Go borrow the deejay’s Viagra, pal, you’re gonna need it. Close second: “Take Me Home Tonight” 9. Billy Joel, “Piano Man.” Billy Joel doesn’t get the kudos he deserves, mostly because people wrote him off as a wimpy balladeer. So what does classic rock radio do? It takes one of the really great songs he wrote, and ruins it for everybody. Close second: “Captain Jack” 10, Bruce Springsteen, “Born to Run.” The next time you hear classic rock radio try to destroy this song, drink 15 beers (or root beers, if you prefer). Then sing at the top of your lungs in your best Jersey accent, like an African bull seal in heat, “I WANNA DIE WITH YOU WENDY IN THE STREET TONIGHT IN AN EVERLASTING PISS!!!” Close second: “Backstreets” or anything off “Born In the USA” Please please please try instead: “Kung Fu Fighting,” “God Save the Queen,” Stretching Out In a Rubber Band” or “Blitzkrieg Bop.” Then again, they’re not Plastic Rock. And I’d rather have them to myself/ourselves anyway.

Ah. I call it my “Bands That Are Past Their Expiration Date” list. Led Zeppelin - Fantastic band, lots of amazing music created… But if I hear Stairway one more time… The Who - Was a time in my life when I, influenced a bit much by my peers, did in fact like The Who. Saw them in concert in 1982. And they put on an amazing show. Excellent show band. Alas. Classic Rock Radio has ruined them forevermore. John Mellencamp - Hold on. I don’t hate him or his music. But I think maybe all of his hits have been beaten to death on the air. Rush - Dear Lord, how I hate Rush. Spare me. Bob Seger, “Turn the Page” - it was a heartfelt song in its day, exuding—no, oozing all the misery of touring. Not to mention forshadowing “Dead or Alive” by Bon Jovi. Another one bites the Classic Rock dust. Pink Floyd - No. Just no. Billy Joel, “Piano Man” - I’m just sooooo sick of it! Elton John, “Candle in the Wind,” both versions - I just can’t. It was lovely, but the grammatical error has always driven me nuts. Neil Young - Gag me with a spoon. The nasal voice… Bleechh. But I do love the song about “flying Mother Nature’s silver spoon”—much better by KD Lang, though. And oh, Lordy, no. More. Doors. While I’m sure that the interminable and infernal organ solo in “Light My Fire” is a delight when you’re stoned, no no no, I don’t smoke it no mo’. (No, that’s not ten songs; I don’t follow directions.) And here are a few that I can listen to over and over and over: Lynyrd Skynyrd, “Free Bird” - yes, really. Fight me. Lynyrd Skynyrd, “Sweet Home Alabama” and a bunch of others. Again, die mad about it. Tom Petty - any and all. Love me some TP & the HBs. The Hollies - If they get played, I’m there. Love their harmonies and Beatley sound. Boz Scaggs, The Police - presented without comment Joe Cocker - any and all, especially live. And finally, my guilty pleasure, Guns ’n’ Roses - yes, really. I am too old and too sophisticated (ahem) to like them, but, Oprah help me, I do.
